verses.text: The LORD visited Sarah as he had said, and the LORD did to Sarah just as he had promised.
verses.comment: God’s faithfulness is shown here as He accomplishes what He promised, a theme fulfilled in the New Testament when God keeps His promises in Christ (cf. Luke 1:37).

verses.text: Sarah conceived and bore Abraham a son in his old age, at the time God had spoken to him.
verses.comment: The miraculous birth echoes later miraculous births in salvation history, culminating in Jesus’ own virgin birth (see Isaiah 7:14; Luke 1:34-35).

verses.text: Abraham called the name of his son who was born to him, whom Sarah bore to him, Isaac.
verses.comment: ‘Isaac’ means ‘he laughs,’ pointing to the joy and fulfillment of God’s promise despite initial disbelief (see Genesis 18:12).

verses.text: Abraham circumcised his son Isaac when he was eight days old, as God had commanded him.
verses.comment: Circumcision as a physical sign of covenant marks Isaac’s belonging, prefiguring the New Covenant’s spiritual sign (see Colossians 2:11-12; Luke 2:21).

verses.text: Abraham was one hundred years old when his son Isaac was born to him.
verses.comment: This highlights the supernatural element of Isaac’s birth, a recurring theme when God intervenes in human history in unexpected ways.

verses.text: And Sarah said, 'God has made laughter for me; everyone who hears will laugh with me.'
verses.comment: Sarah recognizes her joy originates from God’s grace, teaching us gratitude and awe before divine generosity.

verses.text: She said, 'Who would have told Abraham that Sarah would nurse children? Yet I have borne him a son in his old age.'
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes that with God, nothing is impossible—anticipating Christ’s ministry of miraculous power.

verses.text: The child grew and was weaned, and Abraham made a great feast on the day Isaac was weaned.
verses.comment: The feast celebrates God’s gift of new life; throughout Scripture, feasts honor divine mercy and covenant milestones.

verses.text: But Sarah saw the son of Hagar the Egyptian, whom she had borne to Abraham, mocking.
verses.comment: Ishmael’s mocking foreshadows division contrasted later by unity in the people of God brought through Christ (Eph 2:13-16).

verses.text: So she said to Abraham, 'Cast out this slave woman with her son; for the son of this slave woman shall not be heir with my son Isaac.'
verses.comment: Sarah’s concern for Isaac’s inheritance sets the stage for later teachings about spiritual sonship and the fulfillment of covenant in Christ.

verses.text: The matter was very distressing to Abraham because of his son.
verses.comment: Abraham’s grief highlights the tensions between justice and mercy, a theme developed further in God’s redemptive plan.

verses.text: But God said to Abraham, 'Do not be distressed about the boy and your slave woman. Listen to Sarah, because through Isaac your offspring shall be named.'
verses.comment: God’s sovereign choice is underlined, prefiguring His choosing to work through a particular people for salvation.

verses.text: 'And I will also make a nation of the son of the slave woman, because he is your offspring.'
verses.comment: God’s compassion extends to Ishmael, revealing a universal scope to His providence, as seen when salvation is offered to all nations.

verses.text: So Abraham rose early in the morning, took bread and a skin of water, and gave them to Hagar, putting them on her shoulder, and sent her away with the boy. She departed and wandered in the wilderness of Beersheba.
verses.comment: Despite the sorrow, Abraham obeys God, showing submission to divine will even in personal suffering—a virtue modeled by saints throughout salvation history.

verses.text: When the water in the skin was gone, she put the boy under one of the bushes.
verses.comment: The image of being in the wilderness and near death echoes later deliverance stories and points forward to God’s saving intervention.

verses.text: She went and sat down opposite him, a good way off, about a bowshot away, for she said, 'Let me not look upon the death of the boy.' She sat opposite him and lifted up her voice and wept.
verses.comment: Hagar’s cry to God prefigures the cries for deliverance heard throughout Scripture and answered in Christ.

verses.text: And God heard the voice of the boy, and the angel of God called to Hagar from heaven and said to her, 'What troubles you, Hagar? Do not fear, for God has heard the voice of the boy where he is.'
verses.comment: God’s compassion in hearing Ishmael prefigures the effectual prayers of the righteous seen throughout Scripture (James 5:16).

verses.text: 'Arise, lift up the boy, and hold him fast with your hand, for I will make him into a great nation.'
verses.comment: God’s providence and continued blessing toward Ishmael reflects His universal care yet particular covenant blessings through Isaac.

verses.text: Then God opened her eyes, and she saw a well of water. She went, filled the skin with water, and gave the boy a drink.
verses.comment: Water as a symbol of life points forward to the living water Christ offers (John 4:14), showing God as the provider.

verses.text: God was with the boy, and he grew; he lived in the wilderness and became an expert with the bow.
verses.comment: God’s guidance and presence is a theme developed in Christ’s promise to be with His people always (Matt 28:20).

verses.text: He lived in the wilderness of Paran, and his mother took a wife for him from the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: This verse shows the continuing spread of Abraham’s legacy and the importance of familial ties shaping nations.

verses.text: At that time Abimelech and Phicol, the commander of his army, said to Abraham, 'God is with you in all that you do.'
verses.comment: Abimelech’s recognition of God’s presence reflects the witness of the chosen people to surrounding nations, anticipating universal blessing.

verses.text: 'Now therefore swear to me here by God that you will not deal falsely with me or with my descendants or with my posterity, but as I have dealt kindly with you, so you will deal with me and with the land where you have stayed.'
verses.comment: Oaths and covenants reflect the binding seriousness of promises made before God, foreshadowing future biblical covenants.

verses.text: And Abraham said, 'I swear.'
verses.comment: Abraham’s affirmation of the oath reflects faithfulness and integrity, virtues central in Christian moral teaching.

verses.text: Abraham complained to Abimelech about a well of water that Abimelech’s servants had seized.
verses.comment: Disputes over water highlight the necessity and value of peace and justice in community life, echoing later teachings.

verses.text: Abimelech said, 'I do not know who has done this thing; you did not tell me, and I have not heard of it until today.'
verses.comment: Peaceful resolution of conflict is modeled here, prefiguring Christ’s teachings on reconciliation (Matt 5:9).

verses.text: So Abraham took sheep and oxen and gave them to Abimelech, and the two men made a covenant.
verses.comment: Sacrificial gifts as part of covenant-making reflect liturgical practices developed throughout salvation history, showing the centrality of offering in worship.

verses.text: Abraham set apart seven ewe lambs of the flock.
verses.comment: The symbol of ‘seven’ often represents completeness, and offering lambs foreshadows the sacrificial system fulfilled in Christ, the Lamb of God (John 1:29).

verses.text: Abimelech said to Abraham, 'What is the meaning of these seven ewe lambs that you have set apart?'
verses.comment: Intentional acts in covenant rituals signify a deeper spiritual reality, often reflected in worship traditions.

verses.text: He said, 'These seven ewe lambs you will take from my hand, that this may be a witness for me that I dug this well.'
verses.comment: Testimony and remembrance through ritual objects is a pattern recurring in Scripture, and in the life of the Church’s worship.

verses.text: Therefore that place was called Beersheba, because there both of them swore an oath.
verses.comment: Naming places after significant spiritual events invites future generations to remember God’s acts, a tradition that calls believers to honor sacred history.

verses.text: So they made a covenant at Beersheba. Then Abimelech and Phicol, the commander of his army, arose and returned to the land of the Philistines.
verses.comment: Making covenants safeguards peace and exemplifies faithfulness in relationships, a virtue repeated in Christian tradition.

verses.text: Abraham planted a tamarisk tree in Beersheba and called there on the name of the LORD, the Everlasting God.
verses.comment: Planting a tree is an act of remembrance and worship, while calling on the eternal Lord points to the unchanging nature of God, foundational for the Christian understanding of God’s identity.

verses.text: Abraham lived many days as a sojourner in the land of the Philistines.
verses.comment: Abraham’s journey underscores the pilgrim nature of God’s people, living as strangers yet trusting in the inheritance promised—an important theme for understanding salvation history and the communal journey toward God.
